He closes his eyes and smells the cloth... his face tightens in pain... both hands cling to the dress tightly... he tries desperately, can't fight it -- Maurice Parker begins to cry. His hands grab frantically at the rest of the dresses -- pressing them to his face and chest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: MUFFLED SOUND OF HIS CRIES ECHOES

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  PARK - MORNING The neighborhood park.  The trees in full bloom.  Maurice walks down a path leading to the open fields.  Only mothers with strollers and the elderly are out this early.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : PARK BENCH Maurice is seated on a park bench.  Across from him is an ELDERLY COUPLE -- in their seventies.  The OLD WOMAN is frail with tiny eyes that disappear when she smiles.  The husband is a skinny man with a baseball hat that makes him look like a little boy. Maurice watches them silently as they sit and hold hands... Their warm laughs and whispered conversations stinging him. He watches as the old man gets up.  The old woman tries to make him stay, but he playfully pulls away.  She shakes her head like a shy school girl as the old man walks back down the path by himself. The old woman glances Maurice's way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  DOCTORS OFFICE - DAY An obese woman with a hacking cough sits to the left of Maurice... To the right, a man with a patch over his eye.

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  AAA AUTO CLUB - DAY A hip young woman with her forehead wrapped in a headband chews away on a stick of gum.  JOSELLE leans over the counter with Maurice and studies a map.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  NEW STORE - DAY The future Parker Books.  The room sits as empty and barren as before. Maurice sits on the floor against the far wall.  He stares at his new store.  His gaze turns to the window where the guard strolls by.  The guard doesn't notice him. Maurice looks terrible, his eyes red and framed by bags... his skin a yellowish white. He moves to his feet and TURNS OFF THE LIGHTS.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  BOOKSTORE - AFTERNOON Kris unloads the last of a shipment of books.  He moves to Maurice who sits by the window to the street.  Maurice points to a chair across from him and Kris takes a seat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: DAWN A BRILLIANT RED HUE BLANKETS THE HORIZON

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  WYNNEWOOD PENNSYLVANIA - DAWN A BRILLIANT RED HUE BLANKETS THE HORIZON. The suburbs come to life... Men and women leaving for work... School buses picking up their cargo of passengers... Store owners opening their businesses...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : PARKER BOOKS A group of eleven year old boys including the two kleptomaniacs we saw earlier, are standing before a closed door staring at a sign.  They look at each other before heading down the block. The sign reads:  CLOSED - OWNER OUT OF TOWN.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  HOUSE - MORNING The house is eerily silent. Three things lay on the dining table.  A shoulder bag filled with clothes.  A carrying bag with personals.  And a set of maps. Maurice checks the locks on all windows... He places all the food in the refrigerator into a trash bag... He pulls out a drawer and loosens a side panel, a wad of money flops out. Maurice pockets the bills... Maurice walks through the hall with a portable cage.  He stops before Claude's hanging cage... no movement, no chirping.  Maurice stares emotionally for a moment before reaching in and carefully removing CLAUDE'S LIFELESS BODY from the bottom of the cage.  Maurice looks down at the lost pet in his hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  HOUSE - MORNING Maurice buries the bird in the backyard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : DINING ROOM Maurice sits at the table... the essentials laying before him.  He clings to a wallet size photo of Ellen. Maurice stands and gathers his things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  PENNS LANDING - DAY Maurice stands at the edge of the water.  Recreations of historical ships are docked in the harbor.  The old fashioned sails and masts sway in the gentle breeze. The SOUNDS OF A STREET VENDOR catch Maurice's ears.  He turns to see a funnel cake booth in a row of food stalls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: SOUNDS OF A LIVE BAND MIX WITH THE CRIES OF THE STREET VENDORS

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  TWENTY YEARS EARLIER - DAY (FLASHBACK) The harbor is jammed with people.  A street fair is in full swing.  The SOUNDS OF A LIVE BAND MIX WITH THE CRIES OF THE STREET VENDORS... MAURICE -- EARLY TWENTIES... Skinny, dark rich hair.  He yells out from behind a booth of paperback books.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: BELLOWS FOR HER OVER THE CROWD

dialogue.raw_text: : LATER - IN THE FAIR The people are filing out of the street.  Maurice is a whirl wind of activity as people wave dollar bills at him calling out classical titles. Maurice glances over to Ellen's booth.  She is watching him with a big smile.  Maurice gestures to the line with a shocked expression.  Ellen laughs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : FOOD STALL The booths are packing up.  Ellen helps pack away the remaining food.  A book is placed in front of her on the counter.  The book is "Romeo and Juliet."  Ellen looks up to see a very shy Maurice standing before her.  Ellen gives him a smile that melts him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  THE EDGE OF THE WATER - DUSK The water reflects the lights from the harbor.  Maurice and Ellen are standing very close.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  PENNS LANDING - MORNING (PRESENT) Maurice, tears in his eyes, stands in the spot they stood many years before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  STREET - DAY Maurice wiping his brow with a handkerchief.  The Wrangler jeep rolls up next to him as he walks.  Maurice doesn't stop walking as Kris leans over the passenger seat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  PARKER HOUSE - AFTERNOON The wreaths, flowers and bouquet have now tripled in number. They spill onto the lawn and walkway.  A neighborhood dog rummages through the more colorful bouquets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: BEGINS AGAIN AFTER A FEW SECONDS

dialogue.raw_text: : INSIDE The abandoned house.  A TELEPHONE RINGS CONTINUOUSLY.  It stops after a string of rings.  It BEGINS AGAIN AFTER A FEW SECONDS.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  BOOKSTORE - AFTERNOON The dark bookcases echo the RINGS OF THE TELEPHONE.  The answering machine finally picks up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  ADELLE'S HOUSE - AFTERNOON A center-city Town house.  Wall to wall books, "Cognitive Psychology", "Physiology of Behavior", "Abnormal Psychology", "Clinical Psychology", the titles cover every shelf and every tabletop. Adelle Matlin hangs up the phone, and moves to the living room where her husband is reading a paper in his recliner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: CRUSHED COKE CAN FROM THE SIDE OF THE ROAD

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  MOTEL - NIGHT Nighttime.  The empty street ECHOES with the TIRED SHUFFLE OF MAURICE'S FEET. Maurice stops in this tracks and picks up a CRUSHED COKE CAN FROM THE SIDE OF THE ROAD.  He places it upright at the place where he stands.  Maurice immediately walks off the highway into a small MOTEL PARKING LOT.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  MOTEL - NIGHT A motel clerk checks his wooden keys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .  Pay Per View Channels can be -- MAURICE I need a bed and I need Tylenol... that's all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The room comes with two twin Sealy Posturepedics... but the Tylenol will be extra. Maurice stares at him with exhausted eyes.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INSIDE OF A FLORAL PRINTED ROOM
WATER IS RUNNING IN THE BATHROOM

dialogue.raw_text: : THE INSIDE OF A FLORAL PRINTED ROOM Maurice's shoulder bags are on the bed... The WATER IS RUNNING IN THE BATHROOM. Maurice gently moves his hands under the bathtub head, checking the temperature.  He sits on the edge of the tub. Maurice peels off his shoes with great pain.  They slide across the dull white tiles into the corner.  The once well kept English Loafers could be mistaken for trash now. Maurice rubs his barefeet with both hands -- grimacing from the pain.  The tub is almost filled.  Maurice stops the tap. The steam from the water fills the room. Maurice raises his legs with great effort and submerges each leg into the steaming water.  His eyes close with great relief as his body melts into the tub.  Maurice lays his head on the side of the tub... It only takes ten seconds before Maurice's SNORING fills the bathroom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: OUTSIDE OF THE QUAKER MOTEL ON ROUTE 32

dialogue.raw_text: : THE OUTSIDE OF THE QUAKER MOTEL ON ROUTE 32 The neon MOTEL SIGN THROBS RED. SUPERIMPOSED across this image are the words:
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ... MILE 26 CUT TO: EXT.  MOTEL - MORNING Maurice looks down the highway... eyes squinting to block out the sun.  The road winds and dissolves into the horizon... Maurice looks back the way he came -- a second of indecision... the moment passes. Maurice takes a deep breath before moving to the CRUSHED COKE CAN.  He moves to the exact spot where he left the road the night before and begins walking again...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Someone's got a hot story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What time did you get in? Kris Reddy keeps typing.  He spits out the answer after a few seconds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five... Couldn't sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's this one about Kris? 'Blinds or Curtains - The Eternal Question?'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no... 'Boxers Verses Tight Undies - The Battle Continues.' Frank and Seth crack up laughing.  Frank reaches for the printouts... Kris immediately covers them with his hand.  He stares up with a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Read about it on Sunday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smells good, honey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Adelle... Maurice is in the paper. She stares silently at the paper laid out on the table.  The headline beams at her:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  NEWSPAPER BUILDING - MORNING The elevator BELL dings, letting off a cargo of newspaper personnel.  FRANK AND SETH are two of them.  They make their way to the desks... a sea of desks pressed against each other -- each desk has a computer. Frank and Seth come to their corner and stop before a young man, Phillies cap turned backwards, sitting behind an IBM 486 DX... fingers flying over the keyboard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  STREET - DAY Maurice exits an athletic store in a small town.  On his feet a new pair of sneakers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: SHARP PAIN SHOOTS UP MAURICE'S LEG

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  STREET - DAY Maurice as he walks down a winding highway.  His new sneakers shuffling slowly. A SHARP PAIN SHOOTS UP MAURICE'S LEG.  His knees buckle.  The shoulder bags tumble to the ground followed by Maurice himself.  From a distance it looks like he's been shot. Maurice grabs the back of his thigh and tries to straighten his leg out... His face frozen in a painful expression. Maurice rubs his legs slowly -- working the cramp out.  He relaxes a bit as he finally straightens his leg.  Maurice sits there motionless -- eyes glazed... defeated. The SOUNDS OF A BIRD snap him out of his trance.  He looks up to see a PAINTED BUNTING, a bird about six inches in height FLY DOWN from a tree and land on a rock next to him.  Maurice stares at the beautiful bird curiously.  Its body splashed with brilliant blues, reds and greens.  It looks out of place in these mundane surroundings.  Maurice looks around the skies to see no other birds.  The Painted Bunting chirps a few times before taking flight into the air.  It circles over Maurice before disappearing behind the trees. Maurice smiles.  He pulls himself to his feet with great effort. Maurice opens all of his bags and begins emptying the essentials -- the maps, food, a canister of water. Maurice reloads one bag and pulls it over his shoulder with great effort.  At his feet, are the rest of his belonging -- piled on the side of the road. Maurice painfully begins walking again. WE PULL BACK on Maurice's figure walking on the highway... the pile of disregarded things laying by the side... The highway is endless... winding it's way for miles and miles into a fixed dot in the distance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  ADELLE'S HOUSE - MORNING Sunrise on Pennsylvania.  Gerald picks the Philadelphia Gazette off the front porch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : DINING ROOM Gerald flips open the paper as he waits before an empty plate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : KITCHEN Adelle puts the finishing touches on a stack of pancakes. She sets up two plates and brings them into the DINING ROOM Gerald's eyes remain glued to the paper.  Adelle comes to the table, holding the golden pancakes over the table.  She notices the strange look on his face.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Adelle is shocked.  She gazes at an old picture of her uncle printed underneath the headline.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my God. She STORMS off into the kitchen with the golden pancakes. Gerald looks down at his empty plate longingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What would you like us to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Put out a P.B.S.... Or whatever it's called.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .P.B.... He isn't breaking any law.  He's a grown man... He can crawl on his hands and knees to China if that's what he wants to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sergeant, I'm a psychologist and I know the difference between normal whims people have and actions that clearly display psychological problems... My uncle lost his wife and it devastated him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're very sorry about that.  Some of our men were on the scene of the accident.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think my uncle is suffering from a condition called Mania which is linked with depression.  It is a time when an individual will act over-confident, and will act out impractical, grandiose plans. Sometimes these plans can be dangerous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long does this... Mania last?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A couple days to a few months if untreated. Dally digests this information.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I'll see if anyone has spotted him recently.  If I get any information, I'll call you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't wait by the phone.  If he's really been walking this whole time, he's out of our jurisdiction... Adelle looks very emotional... on the verge of tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry he'll be back.  He's in his forties.  He's had no physical training... He'll be back by the end of the week.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice sneaks. Maurice realizes they're talking to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure man, High-Top Nike Cross Trainers with heel supports and air cushioned soles -- They're nasty. The boys keep walking.  Maurice looks down at his sneakers with new-found pride. After a while, Maurice's attention switches back to the cars. One car in question catches Maurice's eye.  A woman consoles a small child who doesn't want to leave the car.  She wipes his tiny tears with her hand and hugs him tenderly.  The little boy's head cradled in her arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought we both wanted the same things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've changed my mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't change your mind. Beat.  Ellen takes a seat on the only sofa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've just decided, is that right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Young Maurice is visibly upset.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ellen, there are two kinds of people in the world -- ELLEN Please not, 'The two kinds of people' speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... People that were made to be parents, and people who were not made to be parents... My parents, were people who were not made to be parents but had kids anyway.  I don't want us to be that way Ellen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can change.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Face it Ellen, I'm not the type of person who reads bedtime stories. But you love me anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (upset) Don't be so sure. Ellen fiddles with her dress.  She bites her bottom lip as she tries not to cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shaky voice) What if something happens to one of us?  We'll be all alone. Maurice loses his hard demeanor and moves next to her.  He lays his hand across her shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing will happen to us.  It's a bleak picture, I know, but we're going to be together till were old and grey and you don't remember my name anymore. Maurice lifts her chin with his hand gently.  She blinks her eyes and a tear rolls down her cheek.  He takes a deep breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me think about it okay. Ellen brightens up immediately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not saying anytime soon.  I'm just saying that maybe we can consider it down the road sometime. Ellen gives her patented glowing smile.  She hugs him with all her strength.  She whispers in his ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you Maurice Parker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can show you the main roads, but that'll add ten miles to your trip. Do you mind ten miles?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, who's truck is this? The man sitting on the hood of the truck, has dark hair and hasn't shaven in days.  This unfortunate gentleman is named DENNY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you and your friends planning on driving soon? Denny gives Maurice a greasy curious look.  He squints his glazed eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes we are.  Who the fuck are you? Maurice, doesn't look scared, in fact he looks angered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't know me from Adam, but I want you to do something for me.  I want you to wait until you sobered up before you get behind the wheel. I know this is out of the ordinary, but one man to another, would you do me that favor? Silence.  Then everyone in the group BURSTS OUT IN DRUNKEN LAUGHTER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you a preacher?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (seething with anger) No, I just don't want anybody dying because I didn't say something when I had the chance. Denny's face goes blank.  No emotion.  His steady gaze almost terrifying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll drive my truck shit-faced if I want to.  You better turn around and walk away preacher.  You don't know who you're talking to. Maurice looks around at the hostile faces and decides on a retreat.  Denny watches Maurice with predatory eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to himself) This is Indiana -- nothing's going to happen to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You need a ride, Preacher? The men walk up to Maurice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No thank you I'll walk. A tall lanky gentleman gestures to Maurice's shoulder bag with his beer can.  Some beer sprays Maurice's feet with the gesture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where you coming from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look gentlemen, I'm late, I need to -- DENNY I've been thinking -- who the hell is this preacher guy?  Coming up to me and my friends?  Looking like he wanted to kick my ass for drinking? Denny gives Maurice that inhuman stare.  Maurice is clearly frightened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I figured it.  You're angry. You lost somebody, because some asshole was drinking. Maurice is frozen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe you lost a son?  A sister?  A wife? Maurice looks up for a millisecond.  Denny doesn't miss it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (stepping closer) A wife?... Did someone piss drunk run into your wife?  Crushed her like a bug.  Snapped her bones?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's enough. Maurice is red with anger.  Denny loves it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh the preacher's getting angry again... (Denny goes ice cold) Tell me something.  Did she die instantly or did she feel every torn muscle and shattered bone? Were you there to help her?  Or were you safe at home when the windshield sliced into her face -- MAURICE I'll kill you! Maurice swings.  Denny easily avoids it.  Maurice doesn't see the first BLOW COMING, IT HITS HIM IN THE CHEST -- Maurice gasps for air as he buckles to the dirt.  Hands grab -- restrain.  A POWERFUL KICK IN THE RIBS -- ANOTHER... LAUGHTER... ANOTHER SET OF VICIOUS KICKS... The road and forest begin to spin... A PAINFUL SLASH ACROSS HIS FACE... Maurice prepares for the next blow... it never comes.  RED AND BLUE lights swirl... Maurice looks up, barely focusing -- a man leans over a car door... The image becomes clearer -- a POLICEMAN stands poised -- gun aimed directly at the men hovering over him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (distorted and slowed) Step away from him now!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Need an I.D. check on a Maurice A. Parker... Grey reads Maurice's license.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Driver's number 22 184 877... (listening) He was assaulted by a group of men just outside Elkhart, Indiana...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is he?... That's good. Gesturing to a young officer at another desk to come over. Dally, cups the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Call Adelle Matlin... tell her we found her uncle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus -- he's walked six hundred miles. Kris glances at the hairs on his arm and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Matlin... good morning. Maurice slowly gets up.  Adelle is in shock as she looks at the stranger before her. Maurice stands in a 'COLTS' football T-shirt, faded jeans and sneakers.  His left cheek is black and blue, and his arm and side are bandaged.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uncle Maurice, you're wearing sneakers?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: High-top Nike Cross-Trainers with heel support and air-cushioned soles.  They're nasty. Adelle wasn't sure what that meant.  She shakes it off and hugs Maurice.  She is visibly relieved to have him in her arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My shift ended an hour ago. Adelle notices the ROSE in Grey's hand.  Grey catches her glance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's for my wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the occasion? Grey looks to Maurice -- they exchange a knowing smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No occasion. Adelle notices the WINK exchanged between Grey and Maurice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can use the conference room, if you want to talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That won't be necessary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can talk on the way back -- I rented a car. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It'll be kind of hard to talk, since you'll be in the car and I won't. Adelle gives Maurice an angry glare -- Maurice holds his ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The conference room is down the hall on your right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And your store?  What about your new store?  What about all your dreams?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have new dreams now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't accept that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe one day -- after you've been married twenty years you'll understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uncle Maurice -- I spent all our frequent flyer miles on a one way ticket here... I have a rented car outside, just listen to me. (beat) Come back with me now, and if you still want to do something like this in a year -- maybe we'll plan a car trip across the country -- Gerald and I will come along -- MAURICE I have to walk -- by myself -- all the way -- every inch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's impossible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's what she asked for... It's what I'm going to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was being symbolic.  What if she asked you to fly to the moon?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd be visiting me at Nasa. Adelle changes gears.  She takes a seat next to Maurice and studies his legs and tired face carefully before uttering the words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispering) What if you don't make it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll make it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you really want to do this... plan it out.  Rest up.  Train for it.  Build up your body.  Plan every stop along the way.  How much money?  Time?  Really do it properly.  This is all so -- by the seat of your pants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No it's not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you take the back roads here?  They're not safe.  You'd know that if you'd planned. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've all ready gone six hundred miles... I can't do it again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you can't redo these six hundred miles when you're rested and ready, how are you possible going to walk another two thousand-five hundred miles in your present condition? Maurice is stumped.  He looks unsure.  He instantly looks on the verge of tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing's going to happen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uncle, the way I was told, if that police car didn't happen down that road, you would be dead right now. That guy Denny, had jumped bail in another state, he's dangerous... They'll be other Dennys, if you don't plan. Maurice stares down at the table -- the life draining from him with every word she says.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ellen, deserves you to do this right.  Really make it -- if you're going to do it.  She deserves it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want this?  It's a long ride. Maurice is stretched out in the back -- his legs propped up on a blanket.  Maurice shakes his head "no" silently. His sad eyes watching the passing scenery.  The speeding car swallows up the miles effortlessly.  Maurice watches the Jackson Liquor Wholesalers whiz by... The painful hills he climbed, gone, in an instant... The school where he watched the children being dropped off, swishes by in a blink... all those miles lost. Maurice shuts his eyes in pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Jackson Liquor Wholesalers - Since 1945" Maurice scans the area... gas station ATTENDANTS... A BEARDED HOMELESS MAN laying next to a heating unit... KIDS eating fast food on old picnic tables... Maurice's gaze steadies on the TRUCK, as the driver fills the tank with gas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll figure everything out when we get there... Oh, he's going to need a lot of help with this... He wasn't even going to come with me, I had to tell him that he could do the walk later if he plans well... I know, but by that time I'll have gotten him some treatment... I just want to get back home before he changes his mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want something to eat? She stares at Maurice covered in a blanket with his back to her... an unresponsive blob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you're feeling a lot of emotions right now.  It's okay to be mad.  It's okay to feel helpless.  It's part of the healing process.  I understand.  I do. Adelle puts the Celica into drive and pulls out onto the highway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was exhausted -- slept the whole way. Adelle and Gerald move to the back door of the Celica.  They open it and stare at Maurice covered by the blanket.  Adelle shakes the blanket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uncle Maurice we're home... Uncle Maurice. Adelle shakes Maurice, who stirs a little as he wakes.  His feet slide out from under the blanket -- Adelle stares curiously at the ARMY COMBAT BOOTS that dangle out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uncle Maurice? Adelle pulls aside the covers... THE HOMELESS MAN, from the gas station, sits up.  ADELLE'S SHRILL SCREAM BLASTS THROUGH THE AIR.  Gerald and Adelle stumble back as the large, bearded man struggles out of the car and looks around the quiet neighborhood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So this is the City of Brotherly Love. The homeless man raises his hand.  He holds up MAURICE'S WELL POLISHED BOOK SOCIETY MEDALLION and kisses it lovingly. Adelle and Gerald stare back speechless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ellen would have loved you. Maurice looks closer -- and notices it's wings.  The feathers bend back -- a dark area at the center.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did that happen? Maurice watches the bird hop around the branch -- unable to fly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shaky voice) It must've hit the window... I think its neck is broken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't bring it in here -- it probably has all kinds of diseases. Ellen finds an eye dropper from the table and fills it with water -- she lets a few drops fall into the birds mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It isn't going to make it Ellen. Let the poor thing go quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It'll make it. Her delicate hand rubs the bird's stomach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (softly) You must miss flying.  Being way up there in the clouds looking down at all of us.  You miss that don't you?  You miss playing with your friends and talking with them... In the SOFT LIGHT of the lamp -- Ellen has transformed into a mother rocking her child to sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maurice!  Maurice!  Come out here. Maurice looks through the window to see Ellen waving to him frantically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't believe it. Ellen hugs Maurice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All he needed was love.  Once you have that, you can do anything. Young Maurice and Ellen watch the bird soar into the blue sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll be all right.  A couple days and you'll be up there again. Maurice carries the bird back to the trees.  He lays it back on the branch.  He stares at it's beautiful coat with a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ellen would have loved you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes I understand, it does sound humorous, but this is a very serious situation. Gerald is cooking.  He gently flips the chicken breast in a butter and garlic sauce.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This smells good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why am I such an authority?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (under his breath) Here comes the resume.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I received my B.S. from the University of Pennsylvania, my P.H.D. from Bryn Mawr College.  I worked three years at the Boston University School of Medicine, during which time I had articles printed in the "Journal of Educational Psychology", "American Journal of Psychology", "Psychology Review" and "Science"... So I think it's safe to say my opinion is valid. Gerald brings the sizzling pan over and divides the steaming dish into both plates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, please find him for me... Officer, I tried... but I brought back the wrong person. Gerald quickly scoops some rice onto both plates.  His mouth is watering as he goes for the utensils. Adelle abruptly stands at her place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop laughing! Gerald gets into his seat at the table just in time to see Adelle angrily hang up the phone.  She stares off into space before unconsciously cleaning the table.  Adelle picks up both plates of food...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Adelle -- Gerald's heart sinks as Adelle pops open the trash can with a tap of her foot and dumps the picture perfect meal into the garbage.  She goes to the sink and rinses the plates completely preoccupied with her thoughts.  She mumbles to herself as she shuts off the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He says he admires him. Adelle storms out of the kitchen.  Gerald sits at the empty table with a fork in his hands.  He shakes his head in disbelief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! The cars IMPACT with a sickening CRUNCH -- BACK TO REAL TIME: The Firebird spins into a guardrail, breaking through it and coming to a stop in a bank of snow. The Volvo isn't so lucky.  It flips from the impact... sliding on its roof, driving through the snow, down the road... It comes to a rest a hundred feet away. SILENCE.  STILLNESS.  The entire event took only seconds. Maurice runs frantically after the Volvo.  The windows are SHATTERED.  Snow has packed into the over-turned car.  No one can be seen inside the vehicle. Maurice kneels down and punctures the wall of snow with his hand.  His arm disappears up to the shoulder.  His face grimacing with the strain.  His arm comes out slowly... A few MUFFLED SOBS ARE HEARD BEFORE the little girl breaks through the wall of snow and slides out of the window.  She lets out a DESPERATE GASP for air as Maurice pulls her out by the wrist. Maurice clears her mouth and face and watches as she coughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (panting) It's okay.  It's all over. Maurice lays her gently against a snow bank, before moving to the other side of the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is she okay? Maurice looks up to see the driver of the Firebird walking towards him.  He looks dazed. Maurice doesn't waste another second and plunges his arm in the snow... deeper than before.  His cheek pressed against the snow, almost laying flat on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (frantic) Oh no... she's wearing a seat-belt. Maurice fishes around... his teeth clenched... He lets out a POWERFUL GRUNT as he pulls back with all his strength -- a woman's WRIST appears first, then the tangled hair and then the body spills out onto the road next to Maurice. The driver appears over the Woman and Maurice and loses it when he sees them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It wasn't my fault.  It wasn't my fault. Maurice, out of breath, clears the woman's face and mouth -- no movement.  No sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on... please... Maurice holds her nose and breaths into her mouth...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please... She doesn't respond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No Ellen... don't die...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything's going to be fine Ellen.  I won't let anything happen to you.  I love you sweetie. Everything's going to be different now. The SCENE BACKS OUT as Maurice comforts this stranger in his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's his story?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His name is Maurice.  He's dancing around everything else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Red flag, man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If he's in trouble with the law -- fine.  Not our problem.  He yanked two people from a car wreck, let's give him some space. Hansen looks in at the drawn, exhausted face of Maurice through the window.  Hansen opens the back door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maurice, you need anything?  Which way were you headed?  We can drive you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No thank you officer.  I'll walk. Hansen throws a sharp glance to Tandy.  Hansen turns back to Maurice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grub?  Food?  How about food?  Our dime at the local diner... Maurice mulls this offer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on man, you're a hero.  In Nebraska we don't let hero's walk around with empty stomachs. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I need to be brought back here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Deal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look like shit Maurice. Maurice takes a couple strained breaths.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Getting old.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long have you been footing it Maurice? Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Too long... (looks around) Excuse me gentlemen. Maurice gets up and heads to the bathroom.  Hansen and Tandy stare at Maurice's shoulder bag laying on his seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Red flags man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not our problem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why so vague?  Why so evasive?  He could be somebody hot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not our problem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's going to look beautiful when he turns out to be that animal who paid a visit to the Steadman's house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This guy's not a murderer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If he is, half the town has seen us take him out for dinner like a couple of jack-asses. That makes Tandy think.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If he's clean, he'll never know about it. Tandy looks to the men's bathroom door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do it quick. Hansen instantly reaches over and begins rummaging through the shoulder bag.  Hansen pulls out a little folder.  He opens the folder to reveal an old certificate.  Hansen shows Tandy the worn piece of paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A marriage certificate?  Who the hell carries their marriage certificate around?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maurice and Ellen Parker... it was issued in Philly... Mr. Maurice Parker has come a long way from home.  Why? Hansen returns the certificate and folder to the bag and leaves the booth quickly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hansen's whipped.  Has to call his wife every two hours or she'll go ballistic when he gets home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: P-A-R-K-E-R.  Right.  Get on the horn with Philly.  Call me here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Line one Sarg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not here. Dally zips his coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the Nebraska state police.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nebraska?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know somebody named -- Maurice Parker? Dally freezes.  He shakes his head as he unzips his jacket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiles) That son of a bitch made it to Nebraska. Dally grabs the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it? Michelle just points down the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... He saved a little girl, and her mother.  Pulled them right out of the car... Kris stands, jaw hanging wide open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is he? Michelle checks her notes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (very soft voice) Umm, Elm Creek, Nebraska. Kris practically falls over.  Michelle scribbles down more quotes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This story is big huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mammoth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Gazette's small huh? Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you saying?  This story is too big for this paper?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (flustered again) Umm, no.  It's just that -- KRIS God damn, you're right... You don't say much Michelle, but what you say is golden. Kris' mind is racing as the C.B. conversation continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (too excited) I was expecting a call. Hansen moves to the phone. Tandy winks at Maurice with a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whipped.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I'm on first name basis with half the city of Philadelphia... Hansen, apparently this guy Parker lost his wife and went a little fruity.  I spoke with his niece, Adelle Matlin and she says to restrain him.  That he's dangerous to himself.  She says to call when we have him in the station.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you taking me? Hansen and Tandy exchange looks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to drop off Tandy at the station and then drop you back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's all right isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. Hansen looks back to the road.  The drive continues in silence.  Tandy checks his watch just when a CLICK -- A HARD WIND -- AND A METALLIC SLAM in quick succession shakes the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell was that? Tandy looks back -- Maurice is GONE.  The back seat empty. Tandy stares out the blackness of the back window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit!  He jumped!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jumped where?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Out of the car.  He jumped out of the god damn car!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did they ask?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I had seen you.  By the way I'm sorry about your wife.  They told me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you... I'm sorry you had to lie.  It must have been difficult.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I asked the officers if you had committed some crime... If they had said 'yes', you would be speaking with them right now. This is the father's own room.  Very sparse as one would expect.  He moves to his bureau and retrieves some pills.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take these, and if you're up to it, try to explain how it is you came to be sitting here. Maurice follows the father's instructions and tightens the blanket around his shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm walking for my wife. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To where?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pacifica, California.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From where?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see. Beat.  The father nods as if this is not shocking news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you believe a person's soul lives on after their death?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Most certainly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that that soul takes part of the person they were on this earth with them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's a reasonable assumption.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want my wife's soul having any doubts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doubts?  About what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About my love for her. The father nods with understanding as if everything became very clear with that statement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't have to prove anything to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not proving to her.  I'm showing her.  And I know I don't have to.  I want to.  I've realized, love is about giving. I'm alive, I can still give to her. I want to give her everything I can. The father studies this stranger before him with great admiration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are some people, including those officers, that are trying to stop me.  They mean well.  But they don't understand.  I wouldn't either if I were them. Maurice struggles with the last words.  He slumps back -- physically drained. The father gets up and takes the empty glass of water from Maurice's hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want you to stay here a few days until you're better.  You're no use to your wife in this condition. The father moves for the curtain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think I'm crazy too. The father turns and smiles warmly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have spent my life dedicated to love.  Love of God.  Love of humanity.  And here you are living through love.  Bathing in it. Using its strength, its magic, its ability to overcome any barrier... If you are crazy, I hope my insanity is not far off. Maurice's eyes well up instantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A large PHOTO OF MAURICE is next to the headline.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi. Maurice looks down to find an adorable little boy, black hair, big eyes and an even bigger grin.  This is three year old ISAAC CALDWELL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, hello.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Isaac... I'm three.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Maurice Parker... I'm much older than three.  Are your parents home? Beat.  Isaac thinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what, I can play baseball with my brothers when I'm bigger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what... I'm just little now, but I'll be big soon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll probably be bigger than your brothers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah! Isaac is happy with this thought. Maurice looks up as MRS. CALDWELL comes to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are you talking to Isaac? Mrs. Caldwell stops as she stares at Maurice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, I'm Maurice Parker.  I'm just passing through and I need to conserve what little funds I have... I need some food and a roof to sleep under for one night... Now I don't look like much, but if there are any things that need to get done around the house -- Mrs. Caldwell doesn't listen, but instead yells behind the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dave... you're not going to believe who's here. Maurice looks at her oddly.  MR. CALDWELL comes to the door; his face lights up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Maurice Parker -- the one walking for his wife. Mr. Caldwell is completely floored.  So, for that matter is Maurice.  Mr. Caldwell puts out his hand with awe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If that ain't fate?... Hi, I'm Dave Caldwell.  I do the copy for the anchor on the evening news down here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evening News?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We did a piece after your story ran in the New York Times. Maurice is truly surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: New York Times? Mrs. Caldwell ushers Maurice in the doorway by the elbow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Someone said they spotted you in town... Mr. Parker, you're a celebrity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you were asleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what... I remembered you were here and I woke up. Isaac walks silently to Maurice... Tip-toeing all the way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your parents would want you to be in bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You tell stories?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh no... I'm not good at that. Very bad in fact... Too late.  Isaac climbs up into Maurice's lap with great effort.  Maurice looks down at Isaac who waits patiently for him to begin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would be exceedingly boring. Isaac waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't do these type of things. Isaac -- still waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See there are two kinds of people in this world. (beat) ... Just a short one okay? Isaac gets in position, cradled in Maurice's arms.  Maurice searches for something to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There was a boy named Isaac who wanted to play baseball, but he was too small and no one would let him play... but he kept practicing by himself -- waiting... He went to every game and sat in the stands with his glove.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what... maybe I ran onto the field and hit a home run.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's telling this story? Isaac points to Maurice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good, now the team had this great big player -- Big Billy.  He was the best.  He had them in the World Super-Bowl-Championship of little kids baseball.  But right before the game, the second best player on the team was suspended because he played a prank on a nice man who owned a book store... When that boy grew up he was convicted on burglary charges and spent fifteen years in prison -- where he belongs. Isaac didn't understand that last part.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyway, Big Billy needed another player so he yelled into the stands.  'Who can play baseball?' And there was a little voice that yelled out, 'Me, I can play.' Everyone turned to see a little boy standing with a glove.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (beaming) That's me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right.  But everyone saw how small Isaac was and laughed... but not Big Billy.  He stared at Isaac carefully and then told him to join the game.  It came to the end of the game.  It was the eleventh or twelfth inning or whatever is the last inning of a game...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay nine.  Big Billy's team was losing and he was on base.  That's when Isaac came up.  He could barely hold the bat... Big Billy winked at Isaac... The ball was pitched -- Isaac hit the ball hard. It soared up and out over the stadium.  Everyone cheered.  Isaac hit a home run and won the game. After the game, Isaac asked Big Billy why he let he play.  Big Billy smiled and said, I wasn't always Big Billy, I was Little Billy first... Isaac and Big Billy went off after the game and read a classic book together.  The end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what -- that was a really good story... Tell it again. Maurice has to smile as Isaac looks up anxiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There was a boy named Isaac who liked to play baseball... WE BACK OUT as Maurice rocks back and forth in his chair. Isaac falling asleep in his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's a nice watch. Maurice looks down at his beat-up Seiko.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've always wanted a watch like that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (unstrapping it) It's yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  I won't take it unless I pay for it... Let's see, that's a pretty nice watch -- I can see that. Maurice watches him suspiciously as he pulls out an envelope from his jacket pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's say I give you what's in this envelope for that beautiful watch. Maurice is handed the envelope.  He opens it to find a thick PILE OF CASH, TENS AND TWENTIES.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I really want that watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This isn't right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is my only chance to get a watch like that.  It would mean a lot to me and my family.  Please take it.  It really isn't that much. Maurice stares into the envelope emotionally and hands over the watch tentatively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a loan. Mr. Caldwell straps on the watch and then hugs Maurice. The rest of the family say their good-byes. Isaac won't let go of Maurice's hand as he walks out into the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isaac, come back here. Isaac just holds on tighter.  After Maurice and Isaac have walked a few steps out into the street, Maurice kneels down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to go now. Isaac's bottom lip protrudes as he tries not to cry.  Maurice has to hold back a few tears himself.  He hugs Isaac tightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers) Why didn't I meet you fifteen years ago? Maurice pulls away from Isaac slowly.  Isaac runs to his mother's arms.  Maurice waves good-bye to the Caldwells as he heads down the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's wrong?  They said something was wrong? Maurice stares at his rented shoes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm fine. Ellen moves to him and kneels before him.  She lifts his chin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone's here.  Everything looks beautiful.  They even got the white dove I wanted for the cake -- so what's wrong?  What is it? Maurice moves his gaze from her to the half open door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's him. Ellen looks back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your father?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's plastered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's okay -- really it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No it's not.  He should be here with me now, not trying to find some fucking bottle of Johnny Walker.  He's never been there for me.  I've always been alone. Maurice looks like he may cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid Ellen... I'm scared of being alone again.  What if one day you realize how boring I am?  What if one day you realize you're not happy? (beat) I could have been alone before, but now you've changed things.  I can't be alone anymore Ellen.  I'm scared what's going to happen to me. Ellen takes both his hands and squeezes them between hers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The day I met you, I gave you my heart.  Today, I give you my soul. Where ever you are, where ever you go, I will be with you.  Maurice Parker, I promise -- (she shakes him with emphasis) I promise, you will never be alone again.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: A PHILADELPHIA NATIVE'S LABOR OF LOVE

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  POLICE STATION - DAY SERGEANT DALLY pretends to be concerned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  HIGHWAYS - DAY A floating DOT moves along a flat stretch of road...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EVENING The sun drops behind rolling hills.  The DOT has become LARGER, sprouting arms and legs...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : NIGHT Darkness has fallen.  The DOT has materializes into MAURICE.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : MOTEL A clerk hands over a set of keys in exchange for money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : ROAD - MORNING Maurice walks back onto the highway and steps next to an old boot that has been used as today's MARKER.  Maurice starts walking from that point.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : DRUGSTORE Maurice grabs two handfuls of small green boxes.  He places them on the table.  The cashier stares down at the eight boxes of Ben-Gay and rings it up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : ROAD Maurice standing at the entrance to a tunnel that pierces the side of a mountain side.  Maurice makes "The sign of the cross" and walks into the darkness...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXIT OF TUNNEL Maurice appears on the other side with a smile of relief. He's awed at the beauty of the landscape.  Tiny clusters of buildings far in the distance wrapped in a blanket of green for miles on every side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : MOTEL Maurice asleep in the bathtub.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : ROAD - DUSK It's raining hard like gun-fire from the sky.  Maurice sits on the edge of a road rubbing his legs.  His hair matted to his head.  The rain pelts the ground in forceful waves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : SUPPLY STORE At a cash register, Maurice slaps ten more boxes of Ben-Gay down on the counter.  A teenage girl with braces looks at him like he's Charles Manson.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : MOTEL Maurice sleeps.  His barefeet are propped up on his bag.  His feet are swollen and red with fresh blisters.  A pack of ice is wrapped around his knee with an old shirt... The picture of Ellen clutched in his hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : ROAD Two joggers pass Maurice as he sees a flashing school sign. It is a suburban town.  The fallen red and orange leaves cover every flat surface. SUPERIMPOSE:  ELKHART, INDIANA... MILE 598 CUT TO: EXT.  SCHOOL - DAY A line of cars pulls around a semi-circle driveway.  Maurice watches as parents drop off their children.  A couple of ten year old boys walk by.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  FIFTEEN YEARS AGO - NIGHT (FLASHBACK) The Parker house many years ago.  The house semi-furnished. Ellen carefully hangs her first bird photographs on the wall; a striking aerial photo of a GOLDEN EAGLE.  Wings spread, soaring high over a mountain range.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: THE CHILD'S SOFT LAUGHTER POUNDING IN HIS EARS

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  INDIANA GRADE SCHOOL - DAY (PRESENT) Maurice walks away from the school, shuffling through the piles of leaves that block the walkways. A child and her father walk down the path towards him. Maurice looks away painfully.  THE CHILD'S SOFT LAUGHTER POUNDING IN HIS EARS as he quickens his pace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  LIQUOR STORE - DAY JACKSON LIQUOR WHOLESALERS.  For the kind of people who buy whiskey by the crate. Maurice has his map unfolded over the cash register.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : OUTSIDE OF LIQUOR STORE The parking lot of the store looks like a used truck lot. Every kind of supped-up truck one could possibly imagine is on display here. Maurice passes a CANARY YELLOW FLATBED PICK-UP with a group of men drinking a newly purchased case of beer.  Maurice gets about ten feet past them when he stops, hesitates and then heads back to them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: SOUNDS OF A CAR GROW IN THE DISTANCE

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  ROAD - DUSK Maurice practically hobbles his way down a road lined by towering pines.  He stops to take a drink from his canister and keeps walking.  The SOUNDS OF A CAR GROW IN THE DISTANCE. Maurice doesn't turn his back. The CANARY YELLOW TRUCK pulls over the ridge with a load full of passengers.  It gains distance on Maurice. Maurice hears the ENGINE and waves HIS ARM IN THE AIR -- signaling for it to pass him.  Maurice walks ten more feet before turning around. Maurice's face instantly changes when he sees the demented grins through the windshield of the truck.  Maurice turns and quickens his pace... The truck picks up pace... Maurice breaks into a run... The truck speeds up, passes Maurice and stops in front of him. Panic fills Maurice as he watches the truck unload it's drunken passengers.  Eyes scan the forest on either side for a way out.  Maurice decides to stand his ground.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: BLOW COMING, IT HITS HIM IN THE CHEST --
A POWERFUL KICK IN THE RIBS -- ANOTHER
A PAINFUL SLASH ACROSS HIS FACE

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  INDIANA POLICE STATION - EVENING OFFICER MERRIL GREY -- balances a phone on his shoulder as he spreads a new coat of mayonnaise on his hoagie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  PHILADELPHIA POLICE STATION - EVENING Sergeant Dally, the officer Adelle spoke to earlier, listens on the other end of the phone his mouth agape.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: UNIT FLOATS THROUGH THE LARGE UNOCCUPIED ROOM
OF DALLY AND OFFICER GREY ARE DISTORTED BUT AUDIBLE

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  PHILADELPHIA GAZETTE BUILDING - EVENING The sea of desks are empty.  One empty desk is lit -- Kris Reddy's desk.  THE CRACKLE OF A SHORTWAVE/C.B. UNIT FLOATS THROUGH THE LARGE UNOCCUPIED ROOM from an adjacent room.  The VOICES OF DALLY AND OFFICER GREY ARE DISTORTED BUT AUDIBLE. WE MOVE TO the back room to find Kris writing furiously in front of an elaborate C.B. setup. He jots down the words as fast as they're said: "Maurice Parker... Elkhart... Route 80... Precinct 18..." The transmission gets cut as the phone conversation ends. Kris quickly rolls the chair across the room and grabs a map off the shelf. The map gets pinned under two coffee cups and a ceramic frog as Kris traces the route from Philadelphia to Indiana... He sits up straight in astonishment as his eyes hit the KEY of the map.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : LATER Kris at his computer and in the 'zone.'  Fingers flying over the keys passionately.  On his desk is a cardboard box filled with letters all shapes and sizes on the verge of overflowing the top of the box.  One the side of the box are the words, "Labor of Love - Fan Mail."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  INDIANA POLICE STATION - MORNING DAWN IN INDIANA -- the sun spills over the horizon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  INDIANA POLICE STATION - MORNING Maurice and Officer Grey are seated on the front stairs of the precinct drinking coffee when ADELLE MATLIN DRIVES UP. Adelle steps out of a RENTED TOYOTA CELICA.  Her tense -- frightened eyes betray her mental state for the past ten hours.  She walks to the stairs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  POLICE CONFERENCE ROOM - MORNING File cabinets in the corners.  A small rectangle table takes up ninety percent of the space in the room. Maurice is seated -- his legs extended straight on another chair.  Adelle paces the front of the room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  CAR - DAY The RENTED TOYOTA CELICA turns out of the police station onto the main road. Adelle holds a cushion in the air as she looks in the rearview mirror.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  GAS STATION/REST STOP - DAY The rented Toyota Celica is parked at the convenience store. Maurice is seated in the back staring out at the eighteen wheelers that come in and out of the parking lot.  He glances in to Adelle who is gathering food. Maurice's dull eyes are about to shut when something catches his attention.  He sits up and stares out the window with great intensity.  Maurice watches as a large truck pulls into the parking lot, across it's side in blazing red --
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: PHONE BOOTH INSIDE THE CONVENIENCE STORE

dialogue.raw_text: : A PHONE BOOTH INSIDE THE CONVENIENCE STORE Adelle is on the phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : CAR - LATER Adelle gets in the front seat of the car keeping the bag of food on the passenger seat.  She starts the car as she talks into the rearview mirror.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  ADELLE'S HOUSE - EVENING Evening in Philadelphia.  The rented Toyota Celica pulls into the driveway.  The front door of the house opens.  Gerald walks out to greet them. A tired Adelle slips out of the car and hugs Gerald.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: ADELLE'S SHRILL SCREAM BLASTS THROUGH THE AIR
MAURICE'S WELL POLISHED BOOK SOCIETY MEDALLION

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  ROAD - MORNING JACKSON WHOLESALER'S PARKING LOT.  The truck from the gas station, the only vehicle parked before the store.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: THE AIR IS FILLED WITH THE SOUNDS OF BIRDS

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  ROAD - MORNING Maurice back on the road.  His limp only slightly visible at this point in the day.  The bandages rubbing him with every step. The highway takes him around a beautiful bend of trees.  THE AIR IS FILLED WITH THE SOUNDS OF BIRDS.  Maurice spots a YELLOW WARBLER, a striking bird about eight inches long with vivid yellow feathers.  It sits elegantly on a nearby branch. He walks towards it -- it stays in position.  Closer.  The bird chirps back at him.  Maurice is within arms reach of the bird.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  PARKER KITCHEN - FIFTEEN YEARS EARLIER (FLASHBACK) The kitchen is a different color.  The refrigerator and appliances are brand new.  Ellen walks in -- something cradled in her hand.  Maurice looks up from his paper to see Ellen move to the sink and lay a motionless bird on the counter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : BEDROOM Evening, just before bed.  Maurice is reading.  Ellen is monitoring the bird closely.  It lays on the bedside table -- wrapped gently with a hand towel.  A morsel of food is lowered into its mouth with a pair of tweezers.  The bird stares blankly at the ceiling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : LIVING ROOM The GRAPHIC IMAGES of the TV FLICKER on Maurice's face.  He glances back to Ellen who talks to the bird cradled in her arms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : KITCHEN Maurice is reading his paper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : BACKYARD Ellen points to the ground.  The little bird awkwardly walks around the porch. The bird's wings BURST into motion -- flapping hard -- catching the wind.  Ellen jumps up and down, bursting with pride, as her little child takes flight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  STREAM - DAY (PRESENT) Maurice is kneeling at a stream by the side of the road.  He gently clears away the dirt from the Yellow Warbler's feathers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  ADELLE'S KITCHEN - DAY Adelle is on the cordless.  Her fingers tapping on the kitchen table angrily.  Gerald moves around her as he sets two plates at the table.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  MIDWEST HIGHWAYS - DAY The land is flat.  From the roads one can see endless fields in all directions.  When the wind blows, the crops bend in unison, changing the shape and texture of the land for a moment and instantly changing back with a snap of the wind. Maurice takes in the beauty of the land through a painful grimace.  Occasionally clutching his right leg in moments of extreme pain. Maurice rests on an abandoned tractor by the side of the road and watches the wind change the fields.  He closes his jacket as the gusts become stronger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : HOTEL The clock clicks past 11:30 am.  Maurice is still in bed -- the curtains drawn.  He crawls out from under the sheets and downs two pills with a glass of water.  He looks bad.  His face pale, his eyes at half-mast.  He wipes unnatural sweat from his brow and melts into the bed again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : STREET Just after dusk.  A small town's main road.  Maurice quietly passes under the street lights. He stares up and tightens the hood on his parka as the first SNOWFLAKE falls into the SHAFT OF THE STREET LIGHT.  Soon thousands of flakes fall into the light...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : GAZETTE BUILDING Kris fields calls frantically as the LIGHTS BLINK ANXIOUSLY on his phone.  The front page of the Gazette is posted on his pin up board.  It reads... "HE MARCHES ON..."  Underneath is A PICTURE of Maurice standing outside his bookstore holding up THE BOOK SOCIETY MEDALLION proudly. A teenage boy gets off the elevator and maneuvers an enormous bag over his shoulder... emblazoned across his back are the words "MAIL ROOM."  The boy comes to Kris and empties the bag on Kris' desk without a word.  Hundreds of letters cascade down swallowing the table top and covering Kris who stares in awe as the letters keep coming.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : MOTEL Maurice is COUGHING PAINFULLY.  He crouches over the edge of the bed and holds his side with every strain. Maurice looks worse than ever.  His hair and shirt are soaked with sweat.  The coughing attack stops.  Maurice take a couple deep breaths before laying back down. His feet are visible -- sticking out from beneath the sheets. They look like someone has beaten them with a stick, swollen and bruised.  They disappear under the sheets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: SOUNDS OF A VOLVO STATION WAGON

dialogue.raw_text: : SNOW COVERED ROADS that stretch into a white oblivion. SUPERIMPOSE:  ELM CREEK, NEBRASKA... MILE 1,564 CUT TO: EXT.  STREET - DAY Early morning.  The branches of the trees are encapsulated in ice.  The snow piled ten inches on every surface.  Maurice, buried deep beneath three layers of clothes, looks around. His breath materializes with every step.  He forces a weak smile at the magical landscape before him.  White.  Pure. Peaceful. The SOUNDS OF A VOLVO STATION WAGON urges Maurice to the side of the road.  As it passes a little girl waves from the passenger window.  Maurice puts on a brave face and waves back. Another CAR ENTERS the picture -- A DARK BLUE FIREBIRD rises over the hill in the opposite lane moving fast, too fast. SLOW-MOTION as the Firebird skids over the ice and the snow -- the driver desperately trying to gain control... The mother in the Volvo hits the BRAKES as the Firebird spins into her lane... Maurice yells out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : A FRIGHTENING FLASH The mother's UNCONSCIOUS face turns into ELLEN.  Her lifeless eyes -- her bruised cheek and forehead.  Her neck at an awkward angle.  Maurice stares down at his wife in horror.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : THE MOTHER being revived by Maurice.  He pushes her chest in counting... push, count, breath... push, count, breath... The mother's BODY TWITCHES, slightly at first -- then obviously... The mother let's out a FEW PAINFUL COUGHS. She takes a breath.  Life quickly returns to her body. Maurice places her head in his lap and hugs her, lightly rocking back and forth.  The tears streaming down his red face.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: THE CAR OFFICER HANSEN AND OFFICER TANDY

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  ROAD - AFTERNOON The police have descended on the scene.  Traffic has been blocked off in both directions.  The LIGHT thrown by the ambulances tints the snow and fields a THROBBING RED. Maurice's face can be seen in the shadows of the backseat of a police car. OUTSIDE THE CAR OFFICER HANSEN AND OFFICER TANDY converse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  DINER - EVENING The end of the meal.  Maurice sits in a booth across from Hansen and Tandy.  They watch as Maurice coughs violently into his napkin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : LATER Maurice returns to the table to find only Tandy seated. Maurice sees Hansen in the phone booth at the far end of the diner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : PHONE BOOTH HANSEN
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  PHILADELPHIA POLICE STATION - EVENING Sergeant Dally packs his things to leave.  He sees the light on LINE 1 LIGHT UP on his phone.  He ignores it.  The clerk sticks her head around the corner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: CRACKLES WITH THE VOICE OF SERGEANT DALLY AND THE NEBRASKA POLICE

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  GAZETTE BUILDING - EVENING The C.B. CRACKLES WITH THE VOICE OF SERGEANT DALLY AND THE NEBRASKA POLICE. MICHELLE, a very introverted intern, stares at the radio astonished.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : A SMALL SIDE OFFICE It now has "KRIS REDDY" etched on it's door.  Kris looks up from his desk at Michelle who stands in the doorway bright red.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : OFFICE Michelle scribbles down notes. C.B./NEBRASKA POLICE
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  DINER - NIGHT Hansen scoffs down his third dessert.  Maurice stares at him oddly. The PAY PHONE RINGS.  Hansen jumps to his feet too quickly. He tries to recover.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : PHONE BOOTH Hansen listens carefully to the officer on the line.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  POLICE CAR - NIGHT The ride progresses in silence.  Hansen and Tandy in the front seat.  Maurice's head is pressed against the back-seat window.  His eyes begin to shut slightly as sleep overcomes him.  The car goes over a BUMP.  Maurice jars awake.  He glances out the window to see a highway sign swish by in the HEADLIGHTS.  'ROUTE 80 EAST'. East?  Maurice looks around quickly at the passing scenery.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: CLICK -- A HARD WIND -- AND A METALLIC SLAM

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  FOREST - NIGHT Maurice staggers through the naked trees.  Thin trees every few feet with no branches.  The snow ankle deep. Maurice braces himself against a trunk, checking his hands. His vision blurs as he stares down at his scraped bloody palms. The forest clears quickly into an open field.  Far in the distance across the field of white is a small pointed building standing alone.  The glow of a LIGHT can be seen through the windows. Maurice trudges through the deeper snow.  Stumbling many times.  The frigid wind pushing him to his knees.  Maurice keeps moving -- the field seems endless...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : DRIVEWAY Maurice's feet hit the snow of the driveway, just as his legs buckle -- his face HITS the snow hard.  He manages to roll over on his back with great effort.  He stares up at the pointed building -- the dull light becoming duller... something blocks the light.  A man.  Maurice feels himself rise into the air as two powerful arms scoop him off the ice. A PRIEST carries him into the doors of a CHURCH.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  BACK ROOM OF CHURCH - NIGHT A dimly lit cathedral.  Six foot six, FATHER BERCHMAN walks down the center isle of the cathedral, through a cloth curtain and into a BACK ROOM where Maurice is sitting in a chair wrapped in a blanket.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  CHURCH - WESTERN HIGHWAY - DAY Father Berchman wraps one powerful hand around a tiny silver cross dangling from his neck.  The other hand waves high into the air at the shrinking figure of Maurice Parker walking through the snow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : HIGHWAY The long trek continues.  The black tar of the roads peek out in spots as the SUN BEATS down on the flatlands.  Maurice drapes his worn scarf around a melting snowman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : RESTAURANT We are looking inside a fancy Center-City Philadelphia restaurant.  Adelle and Gerald are seated by an enormous bay window.  A waiter comes to their table with their main course.  Gerald watches the food being served with great anticipation. Gerald's eyes drift out the window to the magazine stand on the sidewalk... He squints to see better.  Realization hits hard... His eyes light up.  He looks to Adelle and back to the magazine stand. In a mad race for time, Gerald begins to devour the food on his plate.  The waiter and Adelle watch him in shock.  Adelle glances out the window.  Her eyes squint... then light up. She jumps to her feet and grabs Gerald by the arm, a fork full of food drops to his plate.  Gerald looks back at his full plate longingly as Adelle pulls him out of the restaurant. The waiter looks out the window to the magazine stand.  He squints.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : MAGAZINE STAND The NEW YORK TIMES are hung like stockings around the border of the stand.  On the front pages, a singular headline stands out among the others:
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : DINER A red-headed waitress slices a credit card through the machine and waits... Green computer letters blink - "This account has been closed." The waitress returns with the card -- she shakes her head "No" at Maurice who digs into his wallet for cash.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : MOTEL Maurice slides two twenties across the counter to the motel manager.  Maurice checks the remaining bills in his wallet... only a few bills left. In the motel room we find Maurice sitting over the edge of a bed buckled over in a coughing attack.  It finally stops. Maurice flops back to the pillows, completely drained.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : ROADS The flatlands have vanished.  The roads now serpentine through mountain ranges. VIEW FROM THE MOUNTAIN RANGE; Maurice moves like a grain of dust over the black line of the road. Maurice rests every half mile.  He labors up every incline with ultimate effort.  He braces himself with a branch serving as a make due crutch. Maurice spots a small town nestled in the arms of the mountain range.  He begins the journey to rest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : GROCERIES Maurice pays for his food with the last few bills in his wallet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : ROAD Another stick serves as a walking cane.  The multi layers of clothes have been shed for a short-sleeve shirt.  Maurice follows a dirt road that breaks free of the mountains and into the open country again. SUPERIMPOSE:  COALVILLE, UTAH... MILE 2,472 CUT TO: EXT.
